Dear Ms. Edmon:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• For repeat violations, identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
Youth at facility has been provided the wrong medication by staff and was taken to
Urgent Care on 8/28/22.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was received on 09/08/2022 and investigated in collaboration with
the DHHS Specialist.
I interviewed the Chief Administrator (CA) on 09/08/2022, at the facility, in
collaboration with the DHHS Specialist. CA reported she was on vacation on the day
of the incident. She was informed that on 08/28/2022, while staff was passing
medication, Youth A had taken another youth’s medication. Staff 1 took Youth A to
Urgent Care, but urgent care recommended youth be taken to the hospital. Staff 1
took Youth A to Beaumont Hospital; Youth A was monitored for several hours but no
medical treatment was required. CA said Staff 2 was responsible for medication
dispensing on the day of the incident. Staff 1 resigned and left after her shift,
because Youth A’s mother came to the facility and threatened the staff. Chief
Administrator said only staff trained in medication dispensing are supposed to pass
medication. Staff are trained to never leave medication unattended and to make sure
only one youth is taking medication at a time so that mistakes are not made.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility, on 09/08/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS
Specialist. Youth A reported he took another youth’s medication and had to go to the
3

hospital. Youth A said Staff 2 put the medication cups for the other boys on the staff
desk, and she asked Staff 1 to finish passing the medication, while she went to
check on the food in the kitchen. Youth A reported he went quietly behind the staff’s
desk and took another youth’s medication. He said that morning he had already
taken his medication. He reported Staff 1 was giving another youth his medication
when he went behind the desk and took the medication, so no one saw him taking
the medication. He said this was the only time he has taken someone else’s
medication. Youth A reported being upset and crying afterwards, because the other
boys told him he was going to die. He said Staff 1 took him to Urgent Care and then
to the hospital. Youth A was observed to have a band-aid on his left upper cheek.
He said he was involved in a fight with another youth. He reported staff were
present, intervened, and he was examined by the nurse.
I interviewed Youth B at the facility, on 09/08/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS
Specialist. Youth B reported that he receives his medication daily. He recalled the
incident involving Youth A taking the medication and having to go to the urgent care.
He said on the day of the incident Staff 2 gave his medication. The medication was
on the staff’s desk. Youth B denied seeing Youth A taking the medication. He was
asked how staff dispenses medication, and he said staff will bring the medication in
a plastic cup to their room and give it to them one at a time. He denied previously
seeing any medication on staff’s desk. He said all medication is always locked in the
medication room behind the laundry room.
I interviewed Youth C at the facility, on 09/08/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS
Specialist. Youth C reported that he was still sleeping on the day that Youth A took
the medication, and therefore did not see him taking the medication. He said staff
did give him his medication on that day of the incident. Youth C said he gets his
medication daily and that staff bring the medication in a plastic cup with a cup of
water. He said staff will also have them open their mouth to make sure they
swallowed the medication. He reported the medication is always locked in the
medication room and he has never seen the medication left on the staff’s desk.
I interviewed Youth D at the facility, on 09/08/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS
Specialist. Youth D reported he was in the bathroom on the day of the incident and
did not witness Youth A taking the medication. He said Youth A was going around
and saying he took the medication. Youth D reported he took his medication on the
day of the incident. He denied seeing the medication on the staff’s desk. He reported
the medication is always locked up and staff give each youth’s medication one at a
time.
I interviewed Nurse 1 at the facility, on 09/08/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS
Specialist. Nurse 1 reported that she completed a medication count the following day
after the incident involving Youth A and found Youth D’s medication was short one
pill. She is not sure if Youth A took the medication. Nurse 1 said only staff that are
trained on medication dispensing are supposed to pass medication. She said Staff 2
was trained to pass medication, but Staff 1 was not trained to pass medication and
4

should not have been asked to pass medication. Staff are trained to never leave
medication unsupervised, and they are supposed to pass medication one youth at a
time. Nurse 1 is in the process of going through medication dispensing retraining
with all the staff to ensure they are following the medication dispensing policy.
I interviewed Staff 1 via Teams on 09/19/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS
Specialist. Staff 1 has been working at the facility for 10 months and has no
disciplinary reports. Staff 1 reported he was working at Harrison Cottage, with Staff 2
on 08/28/2022, and recalled the incident involving Youth A. Staff 1 said he is not
trained to pass medication. He reported Staff 2 was dispensing and passing
medication. Staff 1 said Staff 2 asked him to finish passing the medication, while she
went to check on the food. Staff 1 said he went to Youth C’s room to give him his
medication. He admitted that there were three cups of medication on the staff’s
desk, while he went to wake up Youth C and give him his medication. He does not
know how many pills were in each cup. When he returned from giving Youth C his
medication, Youth A told him he had taken the other youth’s medication. He denied
seeing Youth A taking the medication. Staff 1 reported he did see white residue on
Youth A’s tongue but is not sure if it was from his medication or the medication that
Youth A claimed he took. Staff 1 contacted the on-call Supervisor and was instructed
to take Youth A to Urgent Care. Staff 1 took Youth A to Urgent Care, and then was
referred to take Youth A to the hospital for monitoring. Youth A was monitored, an
EKG was done, and then Youth A was discharged. Staff 1 reported Youth A did not
have any reaction to taking the medication. He said Youth A was laughing and
acting like his normal self. Staff 1 admitted he is not trained in medication dispensing
and should not have agreed to pass the medication.
I interviewed Staff 2 on 09/20/2022, in collaboration with the DHHS Specialist. Staff
2 has been employed at the facility for 11 months as a Youth Specialist. She was
working on 08/28/2022 with Staff 1 at Harrison cottage. Staff 2 is trained to dispense
and pass medication. She reported Staff 1 is not trained in medication dispensing.
On 08/28/2028 she put the youth’s medication in the paper cups with their initials on
the cup and set the cups on the staff desk. She had passed the medication to three
youths including Youth A. Staff 2 said she asked Staff 1 to finish passing the
medication for three youths, while she went to check on the food and use the
restroom. When she came out of the restroom, Youth A told her he had taken the
other youth’s medication. She does not think that Youth A took the medication,
because he was laughing and acting like his normal self. She admitted that she did
not follow the agency medication dispensing policy, which is to dispense one youth’s
medication at a time, not to leave medication unsupervised, and not to have staff
that is not trained in medication dispensing pass medication. She was very upset
and blamed herself for not following her training. She said Youth’s A mother came to
the facility and threatened her, so she decided to resign. She reported this was the
first time she had asked another staff to pass medication and takes full responsibility
for what happened.
Documentation reviewed for the investigation:
5

• Facility’s medication administration policy. General procedures for preparing
and administration of medication. Policy was consistent with was reported by
staff and nurse.
• Incident report dated 08/28/2022, written by Staff 1. On 08/28/2022 Staff 2
was dispensing medication. Staff 1 placed the medication cups on the staff
desk. Staff 2 asked Staff 1 to finish dispensing the three-remaining
medications. While Staff 1 was passing a resident his medication, Youth A
took the medication that was on the staff’s desk.
• Incident report dated 08/31/2022, written by Staff 3. On 08/31/2022 Youth A
was playing basketball and became frustrated with another youth and pushed
the youth in the chest. The other youth swung at Youth A and scratched his
face.
• Medical record from Beaumont Hospital for Youth A dated 08/28/2022. Youth
was examined and monitored for accidental ingestion of medication. Youth
was monitored, negative symptoms, and no medical treatment required.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Rule 142. (1) An institution shall establish and follow
written health service policies and procedures addressing
all of the following:
(e) Dispensing medication
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation of the rule. The Staff 2 admitted that
she did not follow the agency medication policy for dispensing
and passing medication. Staff 2 dispensed three youth’s
medications at the same time, put the medication in paper cups
with the youth’s initials, put them on the staff’s desk, and asked
another staff member who is not trained in medication
dispensing to finish dispensing the medication.
CONSULTATION:
The Chief Administrator was advised and provided with the
policy FOM 912-1, to document critical incident reports in
MiSACWIS.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

R 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff

(4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the
following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
ANALYSIS: Staff 2 admitted that she did not follow the facility’s medication
dispense policy and therefore she did not perform the duties of
the assigned position. Additionally, DHHS Specialist found Staff
2 unsuitable.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
